Race, Gender & Class, 196–212. ==Overview== Racism is used to divide people into "superior" (better than others) and "inferior" (worse than others) ones to make excuses for mistreating certain ethnic groups. Sexism is the bias, prejudice or discrimination against someone of either sex, typically against women. As a hybrid, gendered racism is related to racially biased views of masculinity and femininity, e.g. bias against women of a certain ethnic group based on their customs. ==Origin== Gendered racism was coinedInvent (a new word or phrase). Oxford Languages. by Dutch-Surinamese sociologist Philomena Essed (1955 ‒ ) to refer to women facing racism and sexism at the same time. Essed said, ==Issues== Those subject to gendered racism often find it hard to know whether others are biased against them because of their race or gender, or both. Nevertheless, both the race and gender of a person is said to intersect to form his or her identity. The person's lived experience is sometimes analyzed based on both his or her race and gender. ==Related pages== * Afrophobia * Antisemitism * Critical theory ==References== Category:Race Category:Gender Category:Racism Category:Society Category:Sociology Category:Anthropology Category:Social sciences
